item.title: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
item.description: Linear transformations and change of basis are widely used in statistics, for this reason I briefly describe the definition of these concepts and how they are related. Eigenvectors The eigenvector of a linear transformation \(A\) is a non-zero vector \(v\) such us the linear transformation of it is proportional to itself: \(Av = \lambda v\)

item.title: Linear Transformation and Change of Basis
item.description: Linear transformations and change of basis are widely used in statistics, for this reason I briefly describe the definition of these concepts and how they are related. Linear Transformation Letting \(V\) and \(W\) be vector spaces, a function \(f: V \rightarrow W\) is a linear transformation if the additivity and scalar multiplication properties are hold for any two vectors \({\mathbf{u}}, {\mathbf{v}} \in V\) and a constant \(c\): \[f({\mathbf{u}}+{\mathbf{v}}) = f({\mathbf{u}}) + f({\mathbf{v}})\] \[f(c{\mathbf{v}}) = cf({\mathbf{v}}).
